page.title: 04ECOLOGY-RIVER WEAR WALK.
page.content: Walking through the Castle woods and by the river banks we saw delicate cow parsley,also named Lady's Lace,growing profusely, while red campion,speedwell cranesbill and stitchwort, ( a pain - reliever in Medieval times), were very common. There was blue ground ivy,too. In some areas, this is dried and used for brewing tea. It was once used by brewers as a substitute for hops. In the castle grounds, we saw primroses, though picking them is illegal,as they are protected plants. There were late celandines, with yellow pointed petals and the delicate, pink herb robert.We also observed white deadnettle, bugle, plantain,shepherd's purse, bird's foot trefoil,woodruff,bistort,vetch,ribwort yarrow, butterbur and ragwort. Back at school, identifying the more unusual ones presented us with interesting detective work. {L.Hardy,J.Patterson.
